title: Should I move into technical writing? If so, how? - Quora

response.answer_text: Technical writer here with 7+ years experience as a technical writer, from startups to a 20,000 person corporation. The money can be good. In the Bay Area where I am, experienced technical writers can make six figures and there's a lot of open jobs (though I can't speak for outside the bubble). In my personal opinion, you don’t need to go back to school (though some hiring managers might disagree). The technical writers I’ve met are a fairly diverse group. Many are English majors with no technical experience. Some, like myself, have some kind of technical background (programming, science, engineering). Some were journalists. Some had technical communication degrees or certifications. Most did not.  The actual skills you need (generally speaking): Good writing/editing skills: duh, although I’d say only ~10% of my jobs have been actual writing. Most of it is editing, formatting, and producing the document.Understanding the technology: this will vary from job-to-job, but if you are generally good with computers, you should be able to learn what you need. I’ve learned new technologies at every job. If you’re documenting how an end user uses complicated software, your past experience in tech support tells me this would probably be easy for you. If you’re documenting really complex high-tech stuff, you won’t be expected to know it well enough to author original content (only the people creating it can do that). You’ll just need to know enough to be able to edit it for grammar and flow and produce the final document. You’d be surprised what you can edit with just surface knowledge of the terms involved. Good people skills: this is key. One of the hardest parts of your job will be dragging information out of extremely busy technical people, navigating company politics to get the resources you need, and hustling to keep busy when work is scarce (particularly common in smaller companies/startups). This is less of an issue if you’re at a larger company that creates enough documentation to necessitate a group of technical writers and someone managing them - though at that point your bigger challenge may be keeping your soul (my one experience as a technical writer in such an environment was less than positive, as you might guess:(Psychological fit: being a technical writer is a lot like being any kind of writer. It can get lonely. The amount of time you spend talking to and collaborating with other humans will be a very small compared to your staring-at-the-screen time. This is one of the hardest parts of the job for me.Tools: The range of technical writing tools is surprisingly large. Some companies will only require you be a power user of Word. Others may require learning a more complex tool like MadCap Flare or FrameMaker. These tools take time to learn, but if you’re good at learning software, it won’t take too long. I learned FrameMaker on the job and was functioning at a basic level within a week. By the time I left a year later people were coming to me with advanced questions.Your biggest hurdle will probably be lack of experience. People want the role ‘Technical Writer’ on your resume, even though, IMHO, this is often short sighted. I’d maybe go for for a technical writer job with less stringent requirements. Perhaps a company that just needs someone to document software similar to what you’ve supported in the past (maybe even in a similar category of software?). Perhaps a company just needs someone to document internal business procedures, or write compliance reports for the government. All of these (very different) activities usually fall under the title “technical writer”. Once you have that first technical writer job and some experience, you'll be in a good position to grow as a technical writer (should you still want it).   Another angle is to start learning a hot technology. For instance, knowing an in-demand programming language can definitely get the attention of a company using that language, even if you only have a rudimentary understanding of it. I got my first technical writing job just because I had an engineering degree in a field the company was active in (and used that knowledge exactly zero times).

In my opinion, you should not chase the salary figures only. I’d recommend you move to techwriting only if it suits your character and if this field seems close to your heart. Because work should be fun, right? I wrote a post about How To Become a Technical Writer. There you’ll find tips and tricks on education and training, building a portfolio, managers’ expectations and many other. Good luck with your career!

To become a technical writer, you will usually need an Associate's degree in either 1 of these fields: JournalismTechnical and Scientific CommunicationsWriting, GeneralBusiness CommunicationsTechnical writers make quite a good salary. Their average salary is around $71,950 per year or $34.59 per hour. The top 10% of technical writers make 6 figures (approx $108,460). Source: Technical Writers Salary
